Package camzup.core

Class Utils

java.lang.Object
camzup.core.Utils
All Implemented Interfaces:
IUtils
public abstract class Utils extends Object implements IUtils
Implements basic math utilities for single-precision numbers.

    static float
    invSqrtUnchecked(float x)
    An inverse square root implementation for single precision real numbers based on the 'evil bit hack' from Quake III, as described by Chris Lomont in "Fast Inverse Square Root." For accuracy, the result is refined three times with the Newton-Raphson method.

    Useful when normalizing vectors or quaternions.

  • Method Details

    • abs

      public static float abs(float v)
      Finds the absolute value of a single precision real number. An alias for Math.abs(float). Relies on bit-masking to remove the sign bit. Equivalent to Utils.max(-a, a).
      Parameters:
      v - the input value
      Returns:
      the absolute value
      See Also:
      • Float.intBitsToFloat(int)
      • Float.floatToRawIntBits(float)

    • acos

      public static float acos(float v)
      A bounds checked approximation of the arc-cosine for single precision real numbers. Returns a value in the range [0.0, pi] : pi when the input is less than or equal to -1.0; pi / 2.0 when the input is 0.0; 0.0 when the input is greater than or equal to 1.0.

      Math.acos(double) defers to StrictMath.acos(double), which is implemented natively. This is not a "fast" alternative.

      Based on the algorithm in Nvidia Cg 3.1 Toolkit Documentation. This cites M. Abramowitz and I.A. Stegun, Eds., Handbook of Mathematical Functions, possibly p. 83, which cites Approximations for Digital Computers by C. Hastings, Jr.
      Parameters:
      v - the input value
      Returns:
      the angle in radians
      See Also:
      • sqrtUnchecked(float)

    • and

      public static int and(float a, float b)
      Evaluates two floats like booleans using the AND logic gate.
      Parameters:
      a - the left operand
      b - the right operand
      Returns:
      the evaluation

    • approx

      public static boolean approx(float a, float b)
      A quick approximation test. Tests to see if the absolute of the difference between two values is less than or equal to IUtils.EPSILON, 9.999999974752427E-7f. Does not handle edge cases.
      Parameters:
      a - the left comparisand
      b - the right comparisand
      Returns:
      the evaluation
      See Also:
      • approx(float, float, float)

    • approx

      public static boolean approx(float a, float b, float t)
      A quick approximation test. Tests to see if the absolute of the difference between two values is less than or equal to a tolerance. Does not handle edge cases.
      Parameters:
      a - the left comparisand
      b - the right comparisand
      t - the tolerance
      Returns:
      the evaluation

    • asin

      public static float asin(float y)
      A bounds checked approximation of the arc-sine for single precision real numbers. Returns a value in the range [-pi / 2.0, pi / 2.0]: -pi / 2.0 when the input is less than or equal to -1.0; 0.0 when the input is 0.0; pi / 2.0 when the input is greater than or equal to 1.0.

      Math.asin(double) defers to StrictMath.asin(double), which is implemented natively. This is not a "fast" alternative.

      Based on the algorithm in Nvidia Cg 3.1 Toolkit Documentation . This cites M. Abramowitz and I.A. Stegun, Eds., Handbook of Mathematical Functions, possibly p. 83, which cites Approximations for Digital Computers by C. Hastings, Jr.
      Parameters:
      y - the input value
      Returns:
      the angle in radians
      See Also:
      • sqrtUnchecked(float)

    • atan2

      public static float atan2(float y, float x)
      Finds a single precision approximation of a signed angle given a vertical and horizontal component. The vertical component precedes the horizontal. The return value falls in the range [-pi, pi] .

      This is not a "fast" alternative to Math.atan2(double,double).

      Based on the algorithm in Nvidia Cg 3.1 Toolkit Documentation .
      Parameters:
      y - the y coordinate (the ordinate)
      x - the x coordinate (the abscissa)
      Returns:
      the angle in radians

    • bitlm

      public static byte bitlm(byte a, int i)
      Gets a bit from a byte at an index, ordered from least to most significant digit. There are 8 bits in a byte, so the index should be in the range [0, 7] . The bit is promoted to a byte.
      Parameters:
      a - the byte
      i - the bit position
      Returns:
      the bit

    • bitml

      public static byte bitml(byte a, int i)
      Gets a bit from a byte at an index, ordered from most to least significant digit. There are 8 bits in a byte, so the index should be in the range [0, 7] . The bit is promoted to a byte.
      Parameters:
      a - the byte
      i - the bit position
      Returns:
      the bit

    • bitslm

      public static byte[] bitslm(byte b)
      Gets an array of bits from a byte, ordered from least to most significant digit, the reverse of a literal. For example, 0b01010011 would yield { 1, 1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 1, 0 } .
      Parameters:
      b - the byte
      Returns:
      the bit array

    • bitslm

      public static byte[] bitslm(byte b, byte[] arr, int i)
      Appends to an array of bits from a byte, ordered from least to most significant digit, the reverse of a literal. For example, 0b01010011 would yield { 1, 1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 1, 0 } .
      Parameters:
      b - the byte
      arr - the array
      i - the index
      Returns:
      the bit array

    • bitsml

      public static byte[] bitsml(byte b)
      Gets an array of bits from a byte, ordered from most to least significant digit, as a literal would be written. For example, 0b01010011 would yield the array { 0, 1, 0, 1, 0, 0, 1, 1 } .
      Parameters:
      b - the byte
      Returns:
      the bit array

    • bitsml

      public static byte[] bitsml(byte b, byte[] arr, int i)

      Parameters:

      arr - the array
      i - the index
      Returns:

    • copySign

      public static float copySign(float magnitude, float sign)
      Returns the first floating-point argument with the sign of the second floating-point argument. An alias of Math.copySign(float, float) .

      When the sign is zero, the return value will depend on the sign of the zero.
      Parameters:
      magnitude - the magnitude
      sign - the sign
      Returns:
      the magnified sign
      See Also:
      • Float.intBitsToFloat(int)
      • Float.floatToRawIntBits(float)

    • copySign

      public static float copySign(float magnitude, int sign)
      Returns the first floating-point argument with the sign of the second integer argument. When the sign is zero, the return value will be positive, as integer zeroes are unsigned.
      Parameters:
      magnitude - the magnitude
      sign - the sign
      Returns:
      the magnified sign
      See Also:
      • Float.intBitsToFloat(int)
      • Float.floatToRawIntBits(float)

    • cos

      public static float cos(float radians)
      Finds the single-precision cosine of an angle in radians. Returns a value in the range [-1.0, 1.0] .

      Wraps around Math.cos(double).
      Parameters:
      radians - the angle in radians
      Returns:
      the cosine of the angle

    • cot

      public static float cot(float radians)
      Finds the approximate cotangent of the angle in radians. Equivalent to dividing the cosine of the angle by the sine, or to 1.0 / tan ( a ) .
      Parameters:
      radians - the angle in radians
      Returns:
      the cotangent

    • div

      public static float div(float a, float b)
      Divides the left operand by the right, but returns zero when the denominator is zero, avoiding the ArithmeticException. This is to simulate the convention of shading languages like GLSL and OSL.
      Parameters:
      a - the numerator
      b - the denominator
      Returns:
      the quotient

    • div

      public static int div(int a, int b)
      Divides the left operand by the right, but returns zero when the denominator is zero, avoiding the ArithmeticException. This is to simulate the convention of shading languages like GLSL and OSL.
      Parameters:
      a - the numerator
      b - the denominator
      Returns:
      the quotient

    • filter

      public static float filter(float value, float lb, float ub)

      lb - the lower bound
      ub - the upper bound

      Returns:

    • fmod

      public static float fmod(float a, float b)
      Applies the modulo operator (%) to the operands. Known in some languages as rem for remainder. An analogous formula would be fmod ( a, b ) := a - b trunc ( a / b ) . When b is zero, returns a. When a is negative and b is positive, the result will be negative. If b is one, use fract(float) or a - trunc ( a ).
      Parameters:
      a - the left operand
      b - the right operand
      Returns:
      the result

    • fmod

      public static int fmod(int a, int b)
      Applies the modulo operator (%) to the operands. Known in some languages as rem for remainder. When b is zero, returns a.
      Parameters:
      a - the left operand
      b - the right operand
      Returns:
      the result

    • fract

      public static float fract(float value)
      Finds the signed fractional portion of the input value by subtracting the value's truncation from the value, i.e., fract ( a ) := a - trunc ( a ) .

      Use this instead of fmod ( a, 1.0 ) or a % 1.0 .
      Parameters:
      value - the input value
      Returns:
      the fractional portion

    • hypot

      public static float hypot(float a, float b)
      Finds the hypotenuse between two values, sqrt ( a2 + b2 ) . Useful when finding the magnitude of a vector.
      Parameters:
      a - the first value
      b - the second value
      Returns:
      the hypotenuse
      See Also:
      • sqrtUnchecked(float)

    • hypot

      public static float hypot(float a, float b, float c)
      Finds the hypotenuse given three values, sqrt ( a2 + b2 + c2 ) . Useful when finding the magnitude of a vector.
      Parameters:
      a - the first value
      b - the second value
      c - the third value
      Returns:
      the hypotenuse
      See Also:
      • sqrtUnchecked(float)

    • invHypot

      public static float invHypot(float a, float b)
      Finds one divided by the hypotenuse of two values, 1.0 / ( sqrt ( a2 + b2 ) ) . Useful when normalizing vectors.
      Parameters:
      a - the first value
      b - the second value
      Returns:
      the inverse hypotenuse
      See Also:
      • invSqrtUnchecked(float)

    • invHypot

      public static float invHypot(float a, float b, float c)
      Finds one divided by the hypotenuse of three values, 1.0 / ( sqrt ( a2 + b2 + c2 ) ) . Useful when normalizing vectors.
      Parameters:
      a - the first value
      b - the second value
      c - the third value
      Returns:
      the inverse hypotenuse
      See Also:
      • invSqrtUnchecked(float)

    • invSqrt

      public static float invSqrt(float value)
      An inverse square-root. Returns 0.0 when the value is less then or equal to zero. Use the unchecked version when the input value is known to be positive.
      Parameters:
      value - the value
      Returns:
      the inverse square root
      See Also:
      • invSqrtUnchecked(float)

    • invSqrtUnchecked

      public static float invSqrtUnchecked(float x)
      An inverse square root implementation for single precision real numbers based on the 'evil bit hack' from Quake III, as described by Chris Lomont in "Fast Inverse Square Root." For accuracy, the result is refined three times with the Newton-Raphson method.

      Useful when normalizing vectors or quaternions. Prefer this over sqrt(float), which depends on this function.

      Contrary to the name, this should not be assumed to be faster than Math.sqrt(double).
      Parameters:
      x - the value
      Returns:
      the inverse square root
      See Also:
      • Float.floatToIntBits(float)
      • Float.intBitsToFloat(int)

    • lerp

      public static float lerp(float orig, float dest, float step)
      Linear interpolation from the origin to the destination value by a step. If the step is less than zero, returns the origin. If the step is greater than one, returns the destination.
      Parameters:
      orig - the origin value
      dest - the destination value
      step - the step
      Returns:
      the interpolated value

    • lerp

      public static int lerp(int orig, int dest, float step)
      Linear interpolation from the origin to the destination value by a step. If the step is less than zero, returns the origin. If the step is greater than one, returns the destination.
      Parameters:
      orig - the origin value
      dest - the destination value
      step - the step
      Returns:
      the interpolated value
      See Also:
      • lerpUnclamped(float, float, float)

    • lerpUnclamped

      public static float lerpUnclamped(float orig, float dest, float step)
      Linear interpolation from the origin to the destination value by a step. Does not check to see if the step is beyond the range [0.0, 1.0] .
      Parameters:
      orig - the origin value
      dest - the destination value
      step - the step
      Returns:
      the interpolated value

    • lerpUnclamped

      public static int lerpUnclamped(int orig, int dest, float step)
      Linear interpolation from the origin to the destination value by a step. Does not check to see if the step is beyond the range [0.0, 1.0] . Rounds the result to an integer.
      Parameters:
      orig - the origin value
      dest - the destination value
      step - the step
      Returns:
      the interpolated value
      See Also:
      • round(float)

    • mod

      public static float mod(float a, float b)
      Applies floor modulo to the operands. Uses the formula mod ( a, b ) := a - b * floor ( a / b ). When b is zero, returns a. If b is one, use mod1(float) or a - floor(a) instead.
      Parameters:
      a - the left operand
      b - the right operand
      Returns:
      the result
      See Also:
      • modUnchecked(float, float)

    • mod

      public static int mod(int a, int b)
      Applies floor modulo to the operands. Returns the left operand when the right operand is zero. An alternative to Math.floorMod(int, int) .
      Parameters:
      a - the left operand
      b - the right operand
      Returns:
      the result

    • mod1

      public static float mod1(float value)
      Subtracts the floor of the input value from the value. Returns a positive value in the range [0.0, 1.0] . Equivalent to GLSL's fract.
      Parameters:
      value - the input value
      Returns:
      the result

    • quantize

      public static float quantize(float value, int levels)
      Reduces the signal, or granularity, of a value. Defaults to signed quantization.
      Parameters:
      value - the value
      levels - the levels
      Returns:
      the quantized value

    • quantizeSigned

      public static float quantizeSigned(float value, int levels)
      Reduces the signal, or granularity, of a signed value. The quantization is centered about zero. Applied to a vector, this yields a crenelated effect. If the levels are zero, returns the value unaltered.
      Parameters:
      value - the value
      levels - the levels
      Returns:
      the quantized value

    • quantizeUnsigned

      public static float quantizeUnsigned(float value, int levels)
      Reduces the signal, or granularity, of an unsigned value. The quantization treats zero as a left edge. Applied to a color, this yields a posterization effect. If the levels are 1 or -1, returns the value unaltered.
      Parameters:
      value - the value
      levels - the levels
      Returns:
      the quantized value

    • round

      public static int round(float value)
      Rounds a value to an integer based on whether its fractional portion is greater than or equal to plus or minus 0.5 .
      Parameters:
      value - the input value
      Returns:
      the rounded value

    • round

      public static float round(float value, int places)
      Rounds a value to a number of places right of the decimal point. Promotes the float to a double, rounds it, then demotes back to a float.
      Parameters:
      value - value
      places - the number of places
      Returns:
      the rounded value

    • scNorm

      public static float scNorm(float normRad)
      A helper method to facilitate the approximate sine and cosine of an angle with single precision real numbers. The radians supplied to this function should be normalized through division by tau. Subtract 0.25 from the input value to return the sine instead of the cosine.

      This is based on the algorithm described in Nvidia Cg 3.1 Toolkit Documentation .
      Parameters:
      normRad - the normalized radians
      Returns:
      the approximate value

    • sign

      public static int sign(float value)
      An alternative to the Math.signum(float) function. Returns the integer 0 for both -0.0 (signed negative zero) and 0.0 (signed positive zero).

      value - the input value
      Returns:
      the sign
      See Also:

      public static float sqrt(float value)
      Finds the approximate square root of a value. Returns 0.0 when the value is less than zero. An alternative to Math.sqrt(double) . Use sqrtUnchecked(float) when the value is known to be positive. Use Complex.sqrt(float, Complex) when the input may be negative and a complex output is desired.
      Parameters:
      value - the value
      Returns:
      the square root
      See Also:
      • sqrtUnchecked(float)

    • sqrtUnchecked

      value - the value
      Returns:
      the square root
      See Also:

    • swapEndian

      public static int swapEndian(int a)
      Swaps the endianness of an integer. For example, a color in the AARRGGBB format, 0xffaabbcc, will yield the BBGGRRAA color, 0xccbbaaff.

      An alias for Integer.reverseBytes(int).
      Parameters:
      a - the input value
      Returns:
      the swap

    • tan

      public static float tan(float radians)
      Finds the tangent of an angle. Equivalent to dividing the sine of the angle by the cosine. An alternative to the double precision Math.tan(double) , this function uses single-precision numbers.
      Parameters:
      radians - the angle in radians
      Returns:
      the tangent
      See Also:
      • scNorm(float)

    • toFixed

      public static String toFixed(float value, int places)
      A quick, dirty representation of a single precision real number as a String to a number of places. Truncates the final digit right of the decimal place. Edge cases:
      • When the number of places is less than one, returns the String of the truncated value.
      • When the value is not a number ( Float.NaN ), returns "0.0".
      • When the value is greater than Float.MAX_VALUE, returns the max value; when less than Float.MIN_VALUE, the minimum value. This truncates positive and negative infinities to these bounds.
      • When the integral contains so many digits that accurate representation is unlikely, such as with scientific notation, defers to Float.toString(float) .
      Intended to serve as an alternative to String.format(String, Object...), which is very slow, and DecimalFormat, which extrapolates values beyond the last decimal place.
      Parameters:
      value - the real number
      places - the number of decimal places
      Returns:
      the string

    • toPadded

      public static String toPadded(int value, int places)
      Returns an integer formatted as a string padded by initial zeroes.
      Parameters:
      value - the integer
      places - the number of places
      Returns:
      the string

    • ubyte

      public static int ubyte(byte a)
      An alias for Byte.toUnsignedInt(byte) . Converts a signed byte in the range [0x80, 0x7f] to an unsigned byte in the range [0, 255], promoted to an integer. Useful when working with colors.

      Defined for cross-language comparison with C#, which uses signed and unsigned versions of primitive data types.
      Parameters:
      a - the signed byte
      Returns:
      the unsigned byte, promoted

    • uint

      public static long uint(int a)
      An alias for Integer.toUnsignedLong(int). Converts a signed integer in the range [-2147483648, 2147483647] to an unsigned integer in the range [0, 4294967295], promoted to a long. Useful when working with colors.

      Defined for cross-language comparison with C#, which uses signed and unsigned versions of primitive data types.
      Parameters:
      a - the signed integer
      Returns:
      the unsigned integer, promoted

    • wrap

      public static float wrap(float value, float lb, float ub)
      Wraps a value around a periodic range as defined by an upper and lower bound. The lower bound is inclusive; the upper bound is exclusive. Returns the value unchanged if the range is zero.
      Parameters:
      value - the value
      lb - the lower bound
      ub - the upper bound
      Returns:
      the wrapped value
